What your numbers suggest is that for your gear and group make up arcane has as much higher theoretical ceiling, not that it is necessarily less affected by pushback. Rawr may also be handling interrupts as cast stoppages, not pushback, in which case the passive fire resistance would be inconsequential. I am admittedly unfamiliar with the program's mechanics.

Arc/Frost lost 132dps and Fire lost 84dps. So Arc/Frost lost 5.6% of it's dps and Fire lost 3.6%. You can ask Kavan how Rawr calculates interrupts but the dps loss predicted for Brutallus has been right in line with what has occured.
#343SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Kavan
This is the relevant calculation regarding pushback in Rawr:

float InterruptFactor = calculations.CalculationOptions.InterruptFrequency * Math.Max(0, 1 - InterruptProtection);
CastTime = BaseCastTime / CastingSpeed + calculations.Latency;
CastTime = CastTime * (1 + InterruptFactor) - (0.5f + calculations.Latency) * InterruptFactor;
The main thing that most don't think about is the difference in cast time. Fireballs are longer so it's higher chance that you'll lose a full 1 second than for AB. Basically the shorter cast time is a sort of protection in itself as you can't lose more than you spent casting already. The only assumption made is that there is no more than one pushback during a single cast of a spell.
#344SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1jasonf
Originally Posted by Roywyn
I don't know what's causing it really.

Arcane Blast, [Ashtongue Talisman of Insight] are bugged (cast - proc - UNHASTED cast - hasted cast).
Light's Grace, Nature's Wrath (paladin/moonkin talents), [Quagmirran's Eye], [Mystical Skyfire Diamond], Netherwind Focus (good old T2!), [Skycall Totem] work properly (cast - proc - HASTED cast - ...).

Some stuff works, some does not, and some has been fixed over time (the druid talent has, as far as I know).
The reason [Ashtongue Talisman of Insight] doesn't work on the next cast is because you've already started casting when it procs.

Has anyone noticed if a fully resisted AB gives an AB stack? If not we can assume that this is the reason it's not working properly. The server would have to confirm that it actually hit and send to the client that the next AB has a lower cast time, but by the time that happens you've already started casting.
#345SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1wadi
Originally Posted by Kavan
This is the relevant calculation regarding pushback in Rawr:

float InterruptFactor = calculations.CalculationOptions.InterruptFrequency * Math.Max(0, 1 - InterruptProtection);
CastTime = BaseCastTime / CastingSpeed + calculations.Latency;
CastTime = CastTime * (1 + InterruptFactor) - (0.5f + calculations.Latency) * InterruptFactor;
The main thing that most don't think about is the difference in cast time. Fireballs are longer so it's higher chance that you'll lose a full 1 second than for AB. Basically the shorter cast time is a sort of protection in itself as you can't lose more than you spent casting already. The only assumption made is that there is no more than one pushback during a single cast of a spell.
That is interesting, and makes sense in the context of the spells cast; but the DPS loss seems out of proportion with what I'd expect in overall lost cast time. at 61 interrupts over 5 minutes you're looking at a minute of lost cast time, I guess I was expecting something more in the 10-15% DPS loss, instead of the <5% range for that kind of interrupt frequency. From a play feel standpoint I actually wonder if you'd really notice it that much if it's that small?

The other question is if Manly is registering 60 Fire pushbacks (he's mitigating 70% already, so more like 200 total registered hits). Looking forward to that fight, hope to see it next week.

However, that said, look at your time stamps. You're fireballs were slightly MORE than 2 seconds apart. Those are 2.1 second cast Fireballs according to your timestamps -- at least after factoring in whatever latency you might have had. #347SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Bisbus
Has anyone noticed if a fully resisted AB gives an AB stack? If not we can assume that this is the reason it's not working properly. It does give a debuff on a full resist.
#348SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Kavan
Originally Posted by wadi
That is interesting, and makes sense in the context of the spells cast; but the DPS loss seems out of proportion with what I'd expect in overall lost cast time. at 61 interrupts over 5 minutes you're looking at a minute of lost cast time, I guess I was expecting something more in the 10-15% DPS loss, instead of the <5% range for that kind of interrupt frequency. From a play feel standpoint I actually wonder if you'd really notice it that much if it's that small?

The other question is if Manly is registering 60 Fire pushbacks (he's mitigating 70% already, so more like 200 total registered hits). Looking forward to that fight, hope to see it next week.
If you make a rough estimate ignoring spell haste and latency then each individual cast has a 61 * 1.5 / 300 = 30% chance to get interrupted. Of these 30% there is 2/3 chance that interrupt will happen during the first second of a cast, 1/3 chance that it will happen after. If the pushback is during the first 1 sec on average you will lose 0.5 seconds (since you lose 0 if you get interrupted at the very start or full second if you get it at 1 second point and we assume the distribution is uniform). On average the pushback on individual spell will be 30% * (2/3 * 0.5 sec + 1/3 * 1 sec) = 30% * 66% * 1 sec = 0.2 sec. So if this was the end of the story the dps lost on average would be 1 - 1.5/1.7 ~ 12%.

So the dps of AB will be 12% lower, similarly for Frostbolt 14% lower. What just happened is both AB and Frostbolt became lower dps, but mana cost also lowered while your mana income stays the same. Since arcane is more or less mana limited that means that since mana income is the same you will be able to get out almost the same ammount of damage. Where the lower dps really makes an impact is during cooldowns. That means the value of each cooldown is about 12-14% lower and that accumulates to the range of 5% over the whole fight. If you would have an example where you're not mana limited (meaning you can spam AB 100% of time) then the overall dps loss would be much closer to 12-14% that you were expecting.
#349SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Rounced
First off, thank you Kavan for clarifying the interrupt issue. Quick favor, would you mind checking to see if 2T4 is working correctly because I am showing a significant dps loss just in regards to Frostbolt as I increase the interrupt frequency (which implies 2T4 isn't doing anything currently).


Originally Posted by wadi
The other question is if Manly is registering 60 Fire pushbacks (he's mitigating 70% already, so more like 200 total registered hits). Looking forward to that fight, hope to see it next week.
I was assuming that Manly was saying 61 instances of his taking damage that would cause pushback not 61 specific instances of pushback. If it was 61 specific instances of pushback with a Fire spec that definitely does change the situation and would clearly make that fight very ugly for Arcane, although not impossibly so. If it was 200 instances of pushback (which is a literally shit ton of interruption basically on par with RoS) I would just wear 2T4, 2T5 and 4T6 and just spam Frostbolts except when blowing cooldowns with Icy Veins where I would be spamming Arcane Blast.

If we took the 200 instances of pushback model as reality then that would be 67% interruption. That would bring Arc/Frost down from 2312 to 1983dps. Wearing 2T4 2T5 4T6 drops base dps to 2244 which would/should be mitigated by Frostbolt having no pushback at all, however since Rawr doesn't seem to currently model 2T4 it is difficult to theorize what the overall dps would end up being.

Definitely would be a much more significant dps loss then would be seen with Fire though. Fire would start at 2308dps (7/8 T6 + Cowl no Skull) and that level of interruption would drop it down to 2056dps. Although it is interesting to note that switching in 2T4 (helm and shoulders) gives 2171dps so in a situation with that much pushback it would be better to break out 2T4 then to stay in normal raid gear. If it's the 21% (61 instances of damage that could have caused pushback) then staying in normal raid gear would yield 2198dps so it wouldn't be worth breaking out 2T4 in that case.

Very interesting to say the least and really can't wait to get to Mu'ruu so I can test out all this theorycraft.
#350SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Kavan
Yes the current version doesn't model 2T4. I added it in for next release.
#351SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Soraxis
I havent done any modelling of this yet so I cannot claim that this can in fact increase the DPS of arcane, but one thing I want to throw out here that I dont think has been discussed yet is the following. As everybody knows, when we're arcane blasting we generally do AB -> FB -> AB -> FB -> AB -> FB until all the debuffs are applied. The reason is because the cast time of the spell is calculated when the spell is started and the mana cost is calculated when it is completed costing more because the debuff gets applied midway. Now the way we do our rotation nowadays is to keep the AB up constantly throughout the fight so that we dont have to waste time reapplying the debuffs after it is dropped. But what if we timed it accurately enough where we did let it drop to decrease the cost of that specific AB cast and still keep the same casting speed. So the new rotation would still apply debuffs as normal, then instead of mixing frostbolts in with the AB casts, it would be pure AB spam, (to the discretion of the mage) frostbolt spam, and at approximately 1 second remaining in the debuff, another AB cast followed if necessary by more frostbolts and then reapply the remaining AB debuffs and repeat the process.

Like I said, I havent done any hard math on this just been running the concept through my head. What I see this bringing to the table are a few pros and logically a few cons.

1) The reduced mana cost of the last AB cast with still the same DPS (if you're looking at that one spell)

2) Extra time has to be spent re-applying the remaining two debuffs, losing approximately 1.5 seconds worth of DPS reapplying. This is presuming that there are only two debuffs left to reapply because the first one should already be there after the 'last' AB cast of the previous rotation.

3) Since you do spend less mana reapplying AB your mana efficiency goes up, as others have mentioned before regarding AB spam, losing the debuff isnt the end of the world because even though their DPS goes down, they have more mana to work with allowing for longer sustained DPS.

4) It might be hard to time this properly without having to sit and wait for the debuff to reach the target remaining time. If a player ever does stop DPSing completely just to do this specific rotation I'm positive that it cannot be beneficial for net DPS.

So yeah...the main reason I havent modelled this on my own yet is because Im having some difficulty figuring out all of the specific numbers. I'm not going out here saying that this is in fact a better way to DPS, I cant really know that at this point but I do know its possible that this can increase DPS marginally if done correctly.

#353SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Zephriel

http://static.mmo-champion.com/mmoc/...skmuruloot.jpg

Mu'ru trinket confirmed 54 haste passive
New caster ring without hit might change some people's setups.
Indeed. From what I can tell, the new ring basically matches [Mana Attuned Band] in DPS value for a well-geared T6 mage, without deriving any of that value from spell hit. Mages who were planning to gun for the Sunflare/Heart combo might want to swap the rings and go for Sunflare/Chronicle to maintain the hit cap.

At first glance, the new trinket appears to be a clear upgrade over [Hex Shrunken Head], as well. 54 haste > 53 damage, and for on-use effects, 320/8 damage > 211/6 damage.

#356SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Zephriel
Originally Posted by Etherealz
I think it's potentially more powerful than a skull if I'm understanding the effects properly. The circle increases dmg / healing by 320 for everyone inside it. If that's the case my assumption is it's the most powerful trinket now.
If you're right, that could pave the way for drum-like "power circle rotations" where casters take turns activating their trinkets to maintain the greatest possible amount of buff time for the raid. But if that's the case, would it apply to anyone in the raid who stands in the circle? Just the caster's party? Or the caster alone? I'm not going to get my hopes up that it's anything but a self-buff until we learn more about it.

Shifting Naaru Silver:
Equip: Improves Spell Haste Rating by 54.
Use: Conjures a Power Circle lasting for 15 seconds. While standing in this circle, the caster gains up to 320 spell damage and healing. (2 minutes cooldown)

Ring of Omnipotence:
+21 Stamina
+14 Intellect
Equip: Improves Spell Haste Rating by 31.
Equip: Improves Spell Critical Rating by 22.
Equip: Increases damage and healing done by magical spells and effects by up to 40.

This ring seems to be definately the best in slot and I guess you can replace Mana Attuned Band and use Chronicle of Dark Secrets as for having the best gear.

#359SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Soraxis
An easy way to do this would be to armory some of the people posting here, since Im already posting though ill just quickly give the basic one. Basic Build

A few things to point out, not all of the talents there are required...I consider pyroblast, blastwave and blazing speed to be fillers instead of actual talents that I aim to get, along the same lines I can also say the same thing for dragons breath as well.. The basic idea is to get -every- spell that increases your DPS, so any of the +crit%, +fire spell damage % and stuff like that is basically mandatory. After that you also always want burning soul for the reduced threat and less chance of pushback (helpful sometimes) and master of elements for the mana returns.

On the frost side, all you need is the 3 in elemental precision and icy veins. Everything else is pretty much preference, I like the imp frostbolt and permafrost so that I can throw fast rank 1 frostbolts that slow more than otherwise but still dont have the chance of putting them through frostbite.

#362SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Soraxis
Originally Posted by codeviper
Hmmm, sorry for changing the subject, but these questions have been bothering me lately.

I have Icon, Serpent Coil Braid, Combustion, and Icy veins. My question is, which combo would yield me the best in terms of damage?

Originally I had Combustion, Icy Veins, Icon, Serpent - As one macro, but now doubt sets in because I was reading that icy veins + combustion was a pretty bad combo just because if you crit consecutively your ignite ticks won't go through. So now I have two macros atm because of that doubt - Icy veins + Icon, and Combustion + Serpent Coil braid. Any help would be greatly appreciated...

On to the other question

Why is that most end game mages are going to 0/40/21? Isn't the current norm 2/48/11, is double Icy Veins that of an increase in terms of damage? I just respeced before I logged off so I could play around with it tomorrow.

Thanks guys, i've learned quite a ton here
I dont know where you read that you lose ignite ticks from the consecutive crits with icy veins. I've heard that its next to impossible to bug it out and -gain- additional ticks, but if you are only fireball spamming (no fireblast or scorch included when you are using your combustion) the only possible change in DPS will be an increase. You can see the following thread that I get my data from.
Rolling Ignites
Long story short, its possible to 'gain' an extra ignite tick if you have hte right cast time and time your casts right. You can also lose an ignite completely if you cast fireblast immediately after another spell that crits as well. For the purposes of this topic however, we can safely say that you will NOT lose any ignite damage from chain critting fireballs.

With that in mind, you should stick with your original macro, as you probably determined, if you have everything stuck together the extra ignites from combustion will crit just that much more with the trinkets and then you're extra spells from icy veins will have that much more damage as well.
#363SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1IcedTeaIsGood
Originally Posted by td-
Skanky said this in the comments under the killshot: "every1 in the circle, even if you are not in group". Barring any nerfs and fights that are anti-stacking, this could be the best trinket in the game for a long while. Without the group utility, it seems a bit weak.
Without the group utility, it is still better than the Hex Shrunken Head. If it does indeed work in groups though, it seems incredibly powerful. Assuming a group of 1 ele shaman, 1 shadow priest, and 3 locks/mages, everyone would have the trinket after a while. So either all five of you blow it at the same time, granting the group a sickening 1600 +damage for 15 seconds, or the effect doesn't stack and you merely rotate it, giving 320 +damage for 75 of every 120 seeconds. If it stacks even further beyond your group, the dps potential it provides on some fights is mind numbing.

#365SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Roywyn
Originally Posted by Pitbuller
"every1 in the circle, even if you are not in group"
You need just 8 trinkets and whole raid get passive 320spell damage if you can stick in one place. Definetly nerffable.
Power Circle - Spells - World of Warcraft
Power Circle - Up to 320 damage and healing granted to the conjuror of the circle. - 20 seconds remaining
Power Circle - Spells - World of Warcraft
Power Circle - While standing in the Power Circle, the caster gains up to 320 spell damage and healing. - 15 seconds remaining.

The first wording suggests it's meant to be only for the one who clicked.
The second wording is ambiguous, it could address the caster of the circle, or the/any caster standing in the circle.


If it works only on yourself, it's like a 54 haste + 240 damage (20s/120s) trinket, Hex being 53 damage + 211 damage (20s/120s) trinket. An upgrade, but not as huge as I'd expect it to be really.

If it's a group buff, it's huge and allows uncontrolled cooldown stacking - your trinkets can't really get a cooldown if someone else clicks their trinket.
We'll just wait and see what Blizzard seemed to have in mind.


Ring of Omnipotence - 21 sta, 14 int, 40 dmg, 31 haste, 22 crit.
If you have a draenei elemental shaman and are not a jewelcrafter, it replaces Ring of Ancient Knowledge, no +hit juggling needed.
If you are a JCer or horde side or don't have totem of wrath, you may recommence the +hit juggling and the "Which piece of old T6?" question.
Mind you that a caster cloak is still missing, as well as a warlock headpiece from Sunwell (more damage stats, no spirit), if they exist at all.
#366SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Lurker
Originally Posted by Soraxis
I havent done any modelling of this yet so I cannot claim that this can in fact increase the DPS of arcane, but one thing I want to throw out here that I dont think has been discussed yet is the following. As everybody knows, when we're arcane blasting we generally do AB -> FB -> AB -> FB -> AB -> FB until all the debuffs are applied. The reason is because the cast time of the spell is calculated when the spell is started and the mana cost is calculated when it is completed costing more because the debuff gets applied midway. Now the way we do our rotation nowadays is to keep the AB up constantly throughout the fight so that we dont have to waste time reapplying the debuffs after it is dropped. But what if we timed it accurately enough where we did let it drop to decrease the cost of that specific AB cast and still keep the same casting speed. So the new rotation would still apply debuffs as normal, then instead of mixing frostbolts in with the AB casts, it would be pure AB spam, (to the discretion of the mage) frostbolt spam, and at approximately 1 second remaining in the debuff, another AB cast followed if necessary by more frostbolts and then reapply the remaining AB debuffs and repeat the process.

Like I said, I havent done any hard math on this just been running the concept through my head. What I see this bringing to the table are a few pros and logically a few cons.

Rest of post >...
It's morning, I haven't had my IV caffeine yet, but what it sounds like you're saying is just the traditional [AB -> FrBx3 -> AB -> restack etc.] rotation. which gives you a 1.5s Arcane Blast at 195 mana (234 2pcT5) on the next rotation instead of a 2.5s AB for 195 mana (234). If that's the case, then it's been around for a long while. If I'm missing a key point here, my apologies.

#370SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1
Edited onPatch 2.4.1		JaMMi
Originally Posted by Roywyn

From the general reliability of in-game GM statements and the sheer potential for overpoweredness, I'd guess it only meant to work for you. But it's kind of pointless to argue about speculation, we can just wait and see.
I agree with the first sentiment. There is no way in hell it will be a group or party buff. You can happily re-quote me this and I will eat my mouse if it is made reality.

I can think of a hundred situations when it would make many of the fights (That I've seen in my pre-Illidan guild, thought I've watched vids of other fights in Sunwell) utterly trivial even if it just affected the party ; so a GM saying it would affect the whole raid is beyond ridiculous.

I will actually eat my mouse if it happens. I'll video it for you.

Edit: I'd like to add that as the poster two above me says ; it's a very clever way to prevent it's (mis?)use in pvp. Generally speaking, a stationary caster is a dead caster ; so by using the circle on the floor mechanic it would be mostly a pve only trinket. Altho BGs ofc like AV would be an exception but again ... no real harm done.

Potentially the mechanic has its pitfalls ; I can imagine some bugs such as encountered with SoC in instances between of the damage going vertically to mobs above the victim ; for example is there a delay on when he/she enters? How long does it last once out ; how does latency affect it ; does it add the damage at the start of the cast or on spell hit? (soulfire at the end of casting normal spells for extra benefit? - I don't know which would be the worst/best example, I'm just suggesting possible flaws in this "circle on floor" idea...

Really, really interesting concept though ; Praise to the developer who suggested it. We've had AoE debuffs for ages, and even buffs (the columns of light in Karazhan, for example) ; but generally the debuffs always work, and the buffs are usually rubbish (delays on entering ; visually you think you're in the effect but the game says you're not and you don't get the benefit ; etc etc) .. so I for one, can't wait to see this in action.
Last edited by JaMMi : 05/05/08 at 12:10 AM.
#371SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Alvira
But if the effect is just only to self, why even bother goign to the trouble of having a circle of effect? Isn't it better to just make it like icon so that you won't lose the buff even if you blink or something?

If the effect extends only to self, there is higher risk because the mage may move out of the circle during the duration of the buff. It only makes sense if the buff can affect more than one person if its a circle. What's the point of having this circle like buff which no one else but the mage can interact with?

I don't think the developers would go to the trouble of coding such a circle if they didn't mean for more than just the mage/cacstor to get the buff. They might as well have just made it an activation trinket like icon, etc if they just wanted the buff to affect only the castor.
#372SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Finkum
As others have stated, by forcing the caster to stay in the circle to receive the buff, the item designers can make powerful PvE burst trinkets without unbalancing arena PvP - as a caster in arena you can't stand in one spot for any length of time unless your opponents are imbeciles (or have no melee).

Also it reinforces the idea that some forethought should be taken before popping cooldowns - ideally you want to pop them when you are going to have 15 - 20s of uninterrupted casting time (or longer with bloodlust). Normally being forced to move by boss mechanic Y just reduces the amount of time you have to cast with the cooldowns active; now you can be forced to forfeit the remainder of the cooldown entirely. Additional strategic considerations like this are a good thing, I think.
#373SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Jarlyn
I think the point is, why bother with the whole Circle mechanic at all if the buff is just meant for you - why not just make it a buff? If you want to enforce the whole no moving thing, make it a buff that cancels when you move. Adding the whole "Power Circle" dynamic seems a total waste of time/code/resources when something equally as effective but much more simple could have been used, if it's intended as a self-buff only. Given these conditions, I don't see why that would be the case.
#374SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Finkum
Causing the buff to be cancelled upon any movement at all seems a bit harsh, and makes the effect less interesting strategically (as there is no analogue to being able to get back into the circle after moving). Additionally the whole "circle of power" thing is a familar (and kinda cool) fantasy concept.

We will just have to wait and see but the consequences of the buff being group- or raid-shareable just seem so extreme. If the buff is stackable you would have insane burst damage potential (5 x 320 = 1600 extra +damage for the duration). If not stackable, then there is still the option to chain use the trinkets back to back, giving the equivalent of 3 Wrath of Air totems or about three tiers worth of gear 62% of the time (if group-shareable only) or 100% if raid-shareable, once you get eight trinkets. If that's not OP, I don't know what is!
#375SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Jarlyn
I don't think it would be tremendously OP if it only applied to your group. Powerful? Sure, but we're talking about the penultimate BC raid dungeon here. Now if it applied to anyone in your raid... yeah, then it starts getting a little crazy. But like I said I just don't see the point of this whole Circle mechanic if it's only intended for you. At any rate the GM admitted it's bugged, so we'll just have to wait and see how it turns out.
#376SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1
Edited onPatch 2.4.1		◊ manly
Originally Posted by Faxmonkey
rolling ignites
My thread specifically said that rolling ignites only occur only on > 2s casts. Sub-2s will not work. Also, all the evidence I have points towards travel time having no real impact on the results. It will, but only indirectly. What causes the bug has got nothing to do with travel time, and is very easy to prove/test using only scorches and/or fireblasts. What you want is to use the time it takes for debuffs to be applied, and get a tick during that time window. This is due to the fact that, as my thread pointed out, not only spell total damage, but the ignite is also calculated upon finishing a cast, but the application of the ignite is delayed. At the time of cast of the 2nd spell, it calculates ignite dmg based on the current ignite_left_to_be_done + current_spell_ignite_to_add. If you get an ignite tick in-between, that tick is free damage. The reason is that the ignite application will take ~100ms, and the rolling ignite behavior is perfectly consistent with the theory.

Originally Posted by Rounced
Manly said that Arc/Frost would be non-viable on Mu'ruu due to the pushback
Please point me where I said that. I was talking about how specs cannot be compared, and about the fact that spell pushbacks don't matter until you reach a fight like m'uru.

When I pointed out that firespec would have the upper hand on supremus due to range, of course I didnt mean that actually would be the spec to go for. I was talking very precisely about range affecting play, which mostly is irrelevant, but under that one example it is particularly nice to have since it allows you to keep range of totems/boss.

I have never said, once, that one spec is not viable. You're merely projecting my answer.
Last edited by manly : 05/05/08 at 1:22 PM.
#377SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Arcanisx
Originally Posted by manly
What you want is to use the time it takes for debuffs to be applied, and get a tick during that time window. This is due to the fact that, as my threat pointed out, not only spell total damage, but the ignite is also calculated upon finishing a cast, but the application of the ignite is delayed. At the time of cast of the 2nd spell, it calculates ignite dmg based on the current ignite_left_to_be_done + current_spell_ignite_to_add. If you get an ignite tick in-between, that tick is free damage. The reason is that the ignite application will take ~100ms, and the rolling ignite behavior is perfectly consistent with the theory.
Since 2.4 though, I haven't been able to get it to work that way. I've only managed to get the extra ignite damage when my fireball crits pretty much on top of the ignite tick. I've had several runs where my Fireball has been midair when ignite ticks and I do not receive extra damage as of 2.4. I'll post a few more samples of WWS on Dr. Boom when I get home. I didn't get too much of a chance to do it this weekend.
#378SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1◊ manly
Well, if you want to test thing, I heavily recommend not fireballing. You could easily make a g15 macro that does scorch and fireblasts 2s after.
#379SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1wadi
Originally Posted by Arcanisx
Since 2.4 though, I haven't been able to get it to work that way. I've only managed to get the extra ignite damage when my fireball crits pretty much on top of the ignite tick. I've had several runs where my Fireball has been midair when ignite ticks and I do not receive extra damage as of 2.4. I'll post a few more samples of WWS on Dr. Boom when I get home. I didn't get too much of a chance to do it this weekend.
I dunno, I think we're sort of splitting hairs about the same thing that's been in game since 2.1. And yes, I screwed up, Arcanis's parses, and indeed all parses that show these extra ticks have fireball casting times of slightly more than 2.0s; not under 2s. What is appealing about this is that there may be a small magic number haste window that will allow consistent rolling ignites. Using the parses Arcanis provided, we can suppose that ignite has a reasonably uniform 100ms delay, and that to consistently hit the window a 2.09s casting speed would be ideal. For fireball, this would mean a haste rating of 684; as the window would appear to be about 10ms long I'd say you could go from 684 to 675 haste and still hit this. Now we just need some data with provided haste ratings to back this up, or show a longer/shorter haste window.

It occurs to me that if you still have your MQG, it would be a very nice trinket to play with for this; as it provides a meaty 330 haste for 20s. Using IV is a little bit of a crutch since it's a mod, and not a flat haste rating bonus.

What is appealing about this is that there may be a small magic number haste window that will allow consistent rolling ignites. I was talking very precisely about range affecting play, which mostly is irrelevant, but under that one example it is particularly nice to have since it allows you to keep range of totems/boss.

I have never said, once, that one spec is not viable. You're merely projecting my answer.

The quote that it is based on is this one, specifically the bolded portion.

Originally Posted by manly

Well, some scenarios will matter more than others. If your guild is hitting a brickwall at eredar twins, for example, then you might want to value extremely highly ice block and cold snap, and its got nothing to do with TC. But for any other fight that I can think of, I wouldn't give a damn about ice block ! You can give me a lot of scenarios, but ultimately, the cases where it matters will vary for each person' opinion because you won't really need ice block until you reach eredar twins. In fact, the only fights I kinda care about right now is brutallus, felmyst and m'uru. To this extent, my valuation of what 'downsides of arcane spec' and what 'downsides of fire specs' are will be naturally very slanted. Since you probably don't know, M'uru is very much the worst anti-arcane fight. Either you aoe non-stop for 5-6min (good luck with that), or you nuke through no less than 63 pushbacks in 5 min (taken from tonights parse). I mean, to me, that just happens to continue to confirm my own beliefs that pushbacks do matter - but if I put m'uru aside, then really pushbacks are non-issue for almost every single fights. As such, until I reach m'uru then, if I were an arcane mage, I would say that pushbacks are non-issue, and you would be right - until you see m'uru. And then your view/weighting on spell pushback from that point on will radically change. So my point here is that you can't either give a bunch of scenarios and compare fire vs arcane, and based on the amount of scenarios where arcane wins vs fire, conclude that spec x is better than spec y. Because ultimately the 'weighting' that each player will give to each scenario will be colored by the perception of the reader.
"worst anti-arcane fight". That statement is very much implying that in your opinion Arcane was non-viable for Mu'ruu. Except that I ran the scenario through Rawr and it showed that the push-back you listed did not hinder dps as much as would be expected.

Originally Posted by Rounced
Manly, 63 instances of pushback over 5 minutes is 21%. Manly posted 63 instances of pushback over 5 minutes, so that's what I calculated it on.
#387SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Jarlyn
Originally Posted by Rounced
please note the math that I posted earlier.
Sure 2198 is > 2191 but I doubt even M'uru is that tightly tuned.
Yeah, he is. Just finished our third night on him this week, and I'm not even remotely exaggerating when I say the entire raid has to be flawless. In regards to your math though, the pushback comes at various times, it's not just a continuous burn on him that can be easily modeled. You have to move around a good bit, probably aoe some (at range), and you'll probably have to sheep multiple times. The real kicker for me was that the aoe is generally done at range - it has to be Flamestrike/Blizzard. I hate to press farther in lieu of the spoiler rules, but as I said I just didn't find Arcane to viable at all for M'uru.

#389SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1JaMMi
Its so refreshing to hear people considering dropping to 2xT4 for a specific encounter. Thoughts like that and TCing around such notions are to me, demanded by trying to be the best at your class or being most useful to any raid you are in. #390SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1◊ manly
Originally Posted by Rounced
please note the math that I posted earlier.

Sure 2198 is > 2191 but I doubt even M'uru is that tightly tuned.

Maybe you just haven't played with the spec enough to be able to maximize it's performance? It's a pretty big difference between the 2 specs and it can take awhile to get used to what is needed to maximize your performance as Arc/Frost.
Yes, and how would you make a fight really bad for arcane ? This is pretty much it. Thats a worst-case scenario, or as close as it gets. Does that means the spec is unable to compete ? Not really. Is arcane bad on Eredar Twins because fire can spellsteal pyrogenics for +35% fire dmg ? Not really. If you want to make a worst-case fire-spec scenario, it would probably involve lots of movement (but not due to range, move like 'move away from volcanos'), have tons of aggro resets, and lots of adds, ideally 6-8 just so that your aoe can't shine, and you can't stack scorch. Or a stream of low hp mobs that constantly come (think vashj-style elementals). Would that scenario make fire unable to compete ? No, it would just particularly suck to be that spec.

My point was specifically about the fact that comparing specs will not work because everyone will value the downsides/upsides of specs differently based on their current content. M'uru is a great example because before that you won't find a place where pushbacks become significant. There was teron back then, but as guilds started to kill it fast it quickly became non-issue (higher icy veins uptime, more bloodlust uptime, all ultimately leading to less impact from pushbacks).
#391SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Underpants
I have a question about the damage values used to derive the relative damage worth of hit/crit/haste points.

I like to do my own calcs when possible, but whenever I see others post ratios they're always much lower valued than my own numbers indicate, so obviously the base assumptions differ somewhere.

Since the damage worth of an added hit/crit/haste point depends on your current average main nuke output, I've always used recent WWS numbers to work out the coefficients. This is to get as true a value as possible, taking all raid buffs into account. However I'm beginning to worry that this makes me overvalue stats like haste (my initial calcs when it was widely itemised told me it really rocked, while many others shunned it outright). Coud someone point out why my model isn't good to use, and which damage numbers are commonly used in gear evaluation?
#392SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Cornelium
I've been discussing with a friend about how multiple firemages improve each other's DPS. Common misconception is that the ability to drop a percentage of the scorching will greatly increase everyone's damage.
I took a mage needing to kill Brutallus (a fight where DPS is the core) and assigned him the best gear available for the level of progression, an elemental shaman and full buffs.
Result was 1480 DPS, 1,36 casting time on scorch, 2018 DPS, 2,73 casting time on fireball. (can change a bit, but it's not relevant). Difference is 538 dps.
Now let's say you are the only firemage in group. You will have to re-cast Scorch every 25 seconds circa, plus the initial stacks. So it's (1,36 * 5)=6,8 seconds intial, plus 353/(25 + 1,36)=13,4 average scorches to be cast, which multiplicated by 1,36, is 18,2 seconds. Adding the 6,8 initial seconds is 25 seconds scorching total. 25 * 1480 = 37000.
Now let's say you can go fireballing for the whole time. We then multiplicate these "scorch seconds" for fireball DPS. 25 * 2018 = 50450
50450-37000=13450 damage difference.
13450/360, which is the fight duration, gives 37 DPS.

Let's take a group with 2 destrolocks, our firemage and an elemental shaman. We want to decide what's best between a second firemage and a moonkin.
By plugging in the same data as before, results give me 2273 DPS (notice i didn't include a SP). A second firemage fully supported by the first (not needing to cast scorch) would then deal 2273 + 37 = 2310 DPS.
I have to admit my knowledge of moonkins is not the highest. However, by playing with Rawr i found out they can deal at least 1929 DPS. Moonkin aura with the right Idol adds 100ish DPS to the firemage, 120ish to the warlocks, and another 100ish to the shaman. 100 + 120 + 120 + 100 + 1929 = 2369 DPS.
It's a net increase of 59 DPS, with the addition of Insect Swarm.

Disclaimer: some maths could be wrong (and most ARE, as it's all calculated on average), and this is but 1 situation over the multiple possibilities. But i find it useful nonetheless.
#393SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Pintofbrew
Moonkins are in that odd position where:

1) They're almost extinct.
2) The ones that did persevere through the adversity of pre-badge loot are extremely driven.
3) Due to the above two facts are cherished by the guilds that have them and sneered upon by the guilds that don't.

While it's very feasible to compare your Nth warlock to your Xth mage because by and large every guild will have at least one more who isn't in the raid of either, it's hard to compare anything to a moonkin given that by and large, guilds either have them and employ them regularly or don't even want to think about them and roll their eyes at the notion.

You also made two rather odd flaws in your calculation:

Firstly, you assume some dps increase to every class you assign a moonkin to. It is rather silly, at this raid level, to put a mage, two locks, a moonkin and an e-shaman grouped with no Shadowpriest on Brutallus. I will very happily stick my hand in the fire and claim the best-case scenario loss of -100dps from losing the mage (probably more because he'll also lose ToW), +40dps from buffing the SP who will take his place, netting a grand "approximately the same as not bringing the moonkin at all" Plus Insect Swarm. Which is rather questionable, given debuff slot availability, though YMMV. I am aware most guilds don't bother even with Scorpid Sting due to debuff slots, which is 2.5x better than Swarm and doesn't require a moonkin.

Secondly, though I feel rather dry and pedantic pointing this out, your disclaimer is rather odd. "calculations are on average" thus "maths are wrong" is an inaccurate statement. I'd venture, "calculations are on average" could only result to "results are on average". Your calculating over a whole fight may be inaccurately representative of what you're debating but it certainly doesn't mean you can't compute numbers.

#395SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Intermission

Yes

#399SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1• Astrylian
It seems like Arc/Frost is more RNG-dependant... "How many AB crits did you get during AP+Hex+SCB+IV/BL?" is alot more important than "How many Fireball crits did you get during Hex+BL?"
#400SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Rounced
Originally Posted by Astrylian
It seems like Arc/Frost is more RNG-dependant... "How many AB crits did you get during AP+Hex+SCB+IV/BL?" is alot more important than "How many Fireball crits did you get during Hex+BL?"
It's a question of degree. Each spec is dependent on RNG but there is a very simple statistical principal in that the more examples you get, the more likely for them to show relevance or the less likely it is for the sample to be outside the range of expected results.

Brutallus Fight.

Fire mage casts 130-140 Fireballs. An Arc/Frost mage casts 55-60 Frostbolts and 150-160 Arcane Blasts or 57% more spells then that Fire mage.

On top of that sample size discrepancy there is the fact that when Arc/Frost blows all it's cooldowns it is using a spell that can only crit for 175% of normal so having a lower percentage of spell crits occur during that small segment of time hurts but is not as significant as for Fire where each crit is 210%.
#401SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Ztorm
Originally Posted by Etherealz
You calculated dps for a 5 minute fight. M'uru has a 10 minute enrage timer.
It doesn't work that way. You don't just sit there and spam at one target the entire 10 minutes. Depending on what role you have, you may need to burn adds, stagger your CDs, AoE, etc.
#402SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Aldor
Just a few replies, my point about IV and AB damage is that AB operates on a damage compression component, it will hurt your DPS if it drops off during IV, but I forgot to mention coldsnap+IV.

Assuming you squeeze all you can out of IV it compensates for a drop off else where.

AB drop off only significantly affect DPS if
1: Your haven't dumped enough mana and a pot timer comes up forcing you to not put pot on cooldown
2: AB falls off during AP/IV
3: The boss dies before you reach zero mana

My point about AB drop off-vs-DPS s that AB drops off due to stop spell casting. Stop casting by and large, will affect any casters DPS.

I made a point about gear and someone made a counter point that in Sunwell Arcane and Fire, as well as DPS in general compete for the same gear, just looking at robes

[Robes of Ghostly Hatred]
would be favorder for Arcane

[Sunfire Robe]
would be favored for Fire
#403SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Rounced

I made a point about gear and someone made a counter point that in Sunwell Arcane and Fire, as well as DPS in general compete for the same gear, just looking at robes

[Robes of Ghostly Hatred]
would be favorder for Arcane

[Sunfire Robe]
would be favored for Fire

except Sunfire Robes does kinda require one to be a tailor.
#404SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Claudio
I'm not exactly sure where to put this but here it goes:

Clear casting channeled spells (arcane missiles or blizzard) triggers the 5 second rule.

I've figure I could mention this since I've seen people mention that you can use clear casting on arcane missiles and get some full mana regen in, when in fact, it doesn't work that way. I don't know if this is a bug or why people don't know it works this way but it does.
#405SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Kavan
Originally Posted by Claudio
I'm not exactly sure where to put this but here it goes:

Clear casting channeled spells (arcane missiles or blizzard) triggers the 5 second rule.

I've figure I could mention this since I've seen people mention that you can use clear casting on arcane missiles and get some full mana regen in, when in fact, it doesn't work that way. I don't know if this is a bug or why people don't know it works this way but it does.
It has always worked this way, people just aren't informed.
#406SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Searix
Well, after a bit of boredom, i decided to test the "rolling ignite" phenom again with patch 2.4

Results:
2.0 speed fireballs: To fast, No rolls
2.05 speed: " "
2.09 speed: http://gfx.nihilum.mousesports.com/a.../2110/8321.JPG
2.19 speed: No rolls

So let's take a look at the one that did work, i underlined the important parts.

Breakdown:
Total crit damage: 1256 + 1294 + 4419 + 4435 + 3964 + 4203 + 3691 = 23262
23262 * .4 = 9304.8 expected ignite damage
Total ignite damage: 510 + 510 + 884 + 1771 + 1678 + 1678 + 1680 + 1680 + 1578 + 1578 = 13547

Ignite did: 58.2% instead of the expected 40%



> What does this mean? <

Well, let's imagine for a second your ignites always rolled like this, the question thus becomes is it worth it?

So, i'll attempt to answer it with this example of our very own Manly's "record" brutallus dps of 2445.
Wow Web Stats
If his ignite did 58.2% instead of the expected 40%, he would have done 65,596 extra damage, or 2645 dps.

That's 200 dps more on an attempt he got 42% crit just because he could('ve) roll(ed) his own ignites.

Or in Layman's terms, 8.17% dps more with a 42% crit rate just if ignites roll.



Discussion
Q: Is a perfect hasted set really viable?
A: Maybe. personal tests indicate you have to get your fireball to within a .01 second, or ~10-15 haste at that level. This means if you get heroism, if you get drums (or depend on it and lose it), etc. any time not spent during that perfect range and you've lost your rolling ignite. Any pushback and you've lost your rolling ignite (although conc aura and icy veins negate it). Can be touchy.

Q: What if i just want to roll ignites during cooldowns?
A: This, suprisingly, is very possible. All you have to do if you can't reach the correct amount of base haste (640 was it?), you just have to have around ~313 haste when you pop icy veins, or ~138 haste base on your gear and pop skull of gul'dan.

OR

Get ~233 haste base on your gear, pop icy veins and drums, and you're also back in rolling range.
That said if you only roll it some of the time you only get that much extra % of rolling ignite respectively

In conclusion if you aim for ignite range you're getting 4-10% or so extra damage, this does however not take into consideration the fact that crit gets exponentially better as you stack it (though quite slowly... however theorertically at 100% crit your ignites stack into infinity). Something to chew on.
#407SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Pintofbrew
The nice thing with rolling ignites is how they work well with Combustion, which aside from it's rolling synergy has been getting worse and worse with each passing patch.

I'd like to examine the relative viability of non-rolling hex-head/skull combo using the familiar "Hex+ flamecap+ Comb, then IV+ Destropot+ Skull" staggering versus perhaps "hex+ flamecap, then Destopot+ Comb+ Skull+ IV+ Just enough haste to get rolling" and see if we can combine absolutely everything under the sun to make a massive roll.
#408SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Yeonora
Originally Posted by Kavan
Originally Posted by Claudio
I'm not exactly sure where to put this but here it goes:

Clear casting channeled spells (arcane missiles or blizzard) triggers the 5 second rule.

I've figure I could mention this since I've seen people mention that you can use clear casting on arcane missiles and get some full mana regen in, when in fact, it doesn't work that way. I don't know if this is a bug or why people don't know it works this way but it does.
It has always worked this way, people just aren't informed.
This is wrong. Clear casting channeled spells does NOT trigger the 5-second-rule. However, you cannot under the current game mechanics get "normal" (out of FSR) mana regeneration while channeling a spell with a base mana cost. That applies to arcane missiles as it does to blizzard or mind control, but it's not directly obvious for arcane missiles as the 5s cast time coincides with the 5s you have to spend without casting to get full out of FSR regeneration again.

If you cast clearcasted arcane missiles, you are out of the FSR, but you gain only "combat" mana regeneration because you are currently channeling. If you cancel your clearcasted arcane missiles after 0.1s of channeling, your next tick will be full out of FSR mana regeneration. If your clearcasted arcane missiles for example last only 2.5s due to haste, you will also gain full out of FSR mana regeneration while casting your next spell (e.g. frostbolt), if it is not a channeling spell like AM or Blizzard again.
#409SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1◊ manly
Originally Posted by Searix
test about rolling ignites
Your results match almost exactly mines. I assume that using fireballs has no real impact on the results, but typically for pure testing reasons I try and avoid them. In my testing I found the window seemed to be roughly 2.07-2.11 for it to work. You can get it to roll outside of those values, but it was fairly inconsistent.

I was thinking about this, maybe the implied delay for adding debuffs also applies for removing debuffs. It would explain the combustion->flamestrike->blastwave behavior amongst other things. It could probably have some potentially unthinked uses if that turns out to be true. However, I am unsure how to test it. I wonder if doing combustion (stack to 10, with 1 charge left), then scorch/fireblast, and see if both spells are 100% crit ? Or maybe the test is very flawed because possibly combustion is wonky and doesn't gets removed until the ignite gets applied (ie: it will be affected by the ignite application delay, which would affect indirectly debuff removal in this case).
#410SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1
Edited onPatch 2.4.1		Rounced
Originally Posted by Searix
Well, after a bit of boredom, i decided to test the "rolling ignite" phenom again with patch 2.4

Results:
2.0 speed fireballs: To fast, No rolls
2.05 speed: " "
2.09 speed: http://gfx.nihilum.mousesports.com/a.../2110/8321.JPG
2.19 speed: No rolls

So let's take a look at the one that did work, i underlined the important parts.

Breakdown:
Total crit damage: 1256 + 1294 + 4419 + 4435 + 3964 + 4203 + 3691 = 23262
23262 * .4 = 9304.8 expected ignite damage
Total ignite damage: 510 + 510 + 884 + 1771 + 1678 + 1678 + 1680 + 1680 + 1578 + 1578 = 13547

Ignite did: 58.2% instead of the expected 40%



> What does this mean? <

Well, let's imagine for a second your ignites always rolled like this, the question thus becomes is it worth it?

So, i'll attempt to answer it with this example of our very own Manly's "record" brutallus dps of 2445.
Wow Web Stats
If his ignite did 58.2% instead of the expected 40%, he would have done 65,596 extra damage, or 2645 dps.

That's 200 dps more on an attempt he got 42% crit just because he could('ve) roll(ed) his own ignites.

Or in Layman's terms, 8.17% dps more with a 42% crit rate just if ignites roll.
Except that it's not 200 more dps, I'm sure that even with his 42% crit rate there were crits that occured in isolation that would only give up a 40% ignite tick and not have any sort of rolling type behavior. You are taking a behavior that occurs in isolated instances and attempting to apply it universally to the entirety of that parse.

On top of that, based on the rest of your findings rolling ignites is a very fickle mechanic. Since it only rolls at exactly 2.09s you really are only getting the rolls to occur when Icy Veins and Bloodlust and the Skull is active (so 20 seconds of rolling behavior out of a ~360 second parse) or if you set up with enough haste gear to get them rolling with just Icy Veins + Skull then you have to plan on not having them roll during Bloodlust since your Fireball will drop out of the ideal zone and will be too fast to cause the rolls. In any case you would only be rolling for 20 seconds during that 6 minute encounter which means you would get 9 Fireballs that could potentially roll not the 123 that Manly cast during that encounter.


Edited to add: I don't want to seem like I am trying to pull the rug out from under people or that I am opposed to ignites rolling, I just don't want anyone posting inflated numbers about the effectiveness of the mechanic. I've been here since the last time mages were thought of as being overpowered (Nax and the huge rolling ignites) and after suffering through the coefficient nerf and everything else that resulted from that the last thing I want the developers to do is to get it in their head that mages are outputting an excessive amount of dps.
Last edited by Rounced : 05/07/08 at 12:30 PM.
#411SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1
Edited onPatch 2.4.1		◊ manly
Originally Posted by Rounced
On top of that, based on the rest of your findings rolling ignites is a very fickle mechanic. Since it only rolls at exactly 2.09s you really are only getting the rolls to occur when Icy Veins and Bloodlust and the Skull is active (so 20 seconds of rolling behavior out of a ~360 second parse) or if you set up with enough haste gear to get them rolling with just Icy Veins + Skull then you have to plan on not having them roll during Bloodlust since your Fireball will drop out of the ideal zone and will be too fast to cause the rolls. In any case you would only be rolling for 20 seconds during that 6 minute encounter which means you would get 9 Fireballs that could potentially roll not the 123 that Manly cast during that encounter.
You missed the part where 2.09s fireballs are possible without any cooldowns. So under the vast majority of the fight (ie: when not using skull or icy veins or bloodlust) this would be possible.

[Sunfire Robe]
[Gloves of Tyri's Power]
[Wand of the Demonsoul]
[Item 'shifting naary sliver' not found!] (54 haste)
[Heart of the Pit]
[Bracers of the Tempest]
[Belt of the Tempest]
[Boots of the Tempest]
[Mana Attuned Band] (or [Ring of Omnipotence] if over hit cap)
[Loop of Forged Power]
[Amice of the Convoker]
[Leggings of Calamity]
[Amulet of Unfettered Magics]
[Item 'sunflare' not found!] (http://www.worldofraids.com/2008/ptr...n/sunflare.jpg - 292dmg, 30 crit, 23 haste)

total haste (not counting gems): 436
gain from RY gems in Y sockets: 6 * 5 = +30 haste
gain from Y gems in Y sockets: 6 * 10 = +60 haste
gain from RY gems in RY sockets: 14 * 5 = +70 haste
gain from RY gems in R sockets + Y gems in Y sockets: 8 * 5 + 6 * 10 = +100 haste
(please note: these numbers ignore the extraneous B or Y socket from headpiece, and assumes CSD metagem req to also use a BY gem)

Possible other items
[Shroud of the Highborne]
[Drums of Battle]
[Brutal Gladiator's Blade of Alacrity] (227 haste, 18 hit)

gain from MH swap only: +204 haste
gain from cloak + perma drums: +112 haste

-----
target: 684 haste (2.09s fireballs) - 436 haste (base set not counting gems) = 248 haste left to be gained somewhere
To get ~248 haste, we have 2 choices:

1- pure haste gems in all Y sockets and RY gem in R sockets (+100 haste), in addition to using a permanent drum rotation, and shroud of the highborne. It is still slightly behind in terms of needed haste, but enough for our purposes. This is somewhat impractical to require permanent drum rotation, but the option is there.

2- use the gladiator MH and gem RY in Y sockets (as I would have had done normally anyway). Drums will possibly mess up the timing, so we have 2 options to work around that;

2.1- not using drums (...)
2.2- run on the 'low-side' of haste, then make drums make you go slightly over the 248 target. 208 'normal' extra haste from base setup, which drums make you jump to 288 extra haste, both of which are OK. This is notably easy to do by dropping gloves of tyri's power for sunfire gloves.
2.3- use only drums in conjunction with your other cooldowns (skull notably). The whole setup is not functional during skull activation anyway, so just stack them as you normally would, and accept that during that time you will get a stacking ignite rather than a rolling ignite. Please note that you could also drum -> swap weapon and not really pay much of a cost for sub-optimal haste gear.

-----
All of those items, save for gloves of tyri's power (which really is a wash compared to sunfire gloves), in the first category are best-in-slots.

Also, you need 43.54% / 684 passive haste for 2.09s fireballs.
Last edited by manly : 05/07/08 at 2:04 PM.
#412SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Rounced
Originally Posted by manly
Stuff...
What to you think is going to happen when a mage posts a parse of them beating the snot out of a double-glaived rogue on a fight like Brutallus using rolling ignites? Cause now that you have shown that the technique is valid and the dps gain is credible it is now a certainty that it will happen.

Arcane Missile haste stacking with the MQG at least had some probability of being a valid technique simply due to the changes Blizzard had implemented that patch that made it actually work and the fact that the changes had made it through the PTR with mages showing that it worked and talking about it and the changes still being implemented.

This is a bit different. Plain and simple it's exploiting a loophole in the caster mechanics. This is especially evident in light of the small cast time window that makes it work in the first place. It's an interesting intellectual exercise but once you get it functioning on a normal basis (which you just showed that it can and will be done) don't be surprised when you get Fire mages nerfed to the same degree as what happened to Rogues and haste stacking with the Warglaives not too long ago.

What I would be most worried about is how they will close the loophole. Easiest fix would seem to be simply removing the stacking component of ignite completely. Sure that will screw over Firemage dps in PvE situations but it definitely seems easier to do (and less disruptive to the game as a whole) then to sit down and try to rework the whole casting mechanic so that it functions well enough to prevent the loophole in the first place.

The alternative theory would be that having ignites roll when cast from 2.09s fireballs was something put into the game by the developers intentionally......
#413SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Ztorm
Originally Posted by Rounced
What to you think is going to happen when a mage posts a parse of them beating the snot out of a double-glaived rogue on a fight like Brutallus using rolling ignites? Cause now that you have shown that the technique is valid and the dps gain is credible it is now a certainty that it will happen.
There's a big difference between the 2.2 AM abuse and rolling ignites. In order to get to a high enough passive haste level without jeopardizing your +spell damage and other stats, you basically need Sunwell level gear and *probably* a 2050 arena rating. The number of mages who have access to these gear requirements will constitute a small minority of the populace. The issue with the Arcane mage in 2.2 was that every mage with a meta-gem slot could do it; a larger proportion of the community was abusing it. Additionally, there is still an RNG factor with the rolling ignites (depending on when your crits occur). Even if a mage does beat the crap out of a double-warglaived rogue, it won't happen frequently. Finally, as you've mentioned in your post, it's going to be hard for Blizzard to close the loophole unless they change how their servers register spell hits/debuffs, or they nerf the crap out of ignite. I doubt they'll do the later, as that will effect the mage community more than a handful of mages posting rogue-like numbers on brutallus.
#414SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Lemming
So I'm not terribly familiar with all the rolling ignite "mechanics" (or bug, whatever you want to call it) but I have been trying to keep up with this thread, and read most of the other thread. I have had another thought that I don't think I've see mentioned.

From what I understand, everyone is doing base calculations for getting the rolling effects off the first ignite tick. I think I saw somewhere a screenshot of someone actually getting a rolling ignite off the *second* ignite tick. If this is true, is there any kind of reliable way to get that to repeat? As I see it here is a possible scenario:

Assumptions:
-It takes ~1s for ignite debuff to appear, then ticks in 2s intergrals. So first ignite is at 3s, second is at 5s (numbers can be adjusted for more accurate numbers, I just don't remember if we ever came up with a set number for the delay)
-The ~2.1s cast fireballs work for rolling ignites because of the delay + travel time of fireball and causes consecutive crits to be almost on top of ignite ticks.

Goal: Crit fireball (2 ignite ticks + noncrit fireball) Crit fireball + rolling ignite

So basically, we want our second crit to land at the time of the second ignite tick. With 2.1s fireballs, I don't believe it will roll on the second tick because there is a flat 2s between ticks, aka no delay. I would assume then you need a longer cast time on your fireballs, somewhere in the vicinity of 2.3-2.4s maybe?


Again, this is based off the assumption that you can roll ignites off the second tick as well. So if I am wrong you can just ignore me as some crazy guy rambling. And of course it works on every-other fireball crits, not consecutive crits. I would think this would be doable with gear available now, but I have all of 5 spell haste right now since I haven't been raiding in quite awhile (I could check and see if I have my trusty mqg somewhere, but even then i'm not sure if i could test it).

Thoughts?

The simpliest fix is to remove ignite dot and apply it directly as part of fireball. I'm sure everyone would highly rejoice of the change. Although you would want to make it explicit that the talent 'ignite' gives 210% crit rates total, which would be quite awkward to word out.

I would be extremely happy if my fireballs critted directly for 210%. It would have other small ramifications elsewhere, such as CSD, but overall I don't even think it would be a negative change. I don't think it would change much on the pvp front, except maybe giving arcane/fire too much burst ? To be honest I think its a wash but thats just me. I can't find any compelling reason to keep ignite the way it is -- all it does is induce frustration.

#416SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1◊ manly
Originally Posted by Lemming
stuff
Without delving into repeating the stuff over, you can roll ignites on both the first and last tick. Travel time is mostly inconsequential, particularly given the standard assumption that both you and the boss doesn't move. It does comes into play when you scorch/fireblast but besides that the impact of it is rather minor.
#417SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Rounced
Originally Posted by Ztorm
There's a big difference between the 2.2 AM abuse and rolling ignites. In order to get to a high enough passive haste level without jeopardizing your +spell damage and other stats, you basically need Sunwell level gear and *probably* a 2050 arena rating. The number of mages who have access to these gear requirements will constitute a small minority of the populace. The issue with the Arcane mage in 2.2 was that every mage with a meta-gem slot could do it; a larger proportion of the community was abusing it. Additionally, there is still an RNG factor with the rolling ignites (depending on when your crits occur). Even if a mage does beat the crap out of a double-warglaived rogue, it won't happen frequently. Finally, as you've mentioned in your post, it's going to be hard for Blizzard to close the loophole unless they change how their servers register spell hits/debuffs, or they nerf the crap out of ignite. I doubt they'll do the later, as that will effect the mage community more than a handful of mages posting rogue-like numbers on brutallus.
The other difference was that a 2.2 AM abusing mage would still be well under the dps of warglaived rogues and barely equal to destro-locks. From what this is looking like Firemages will beat the tar outta both of those easily RNG or not.



Manly, 210% without any DoT being involved won't happen since the reason it is 210% is to offset the delay in having the damage applied and the chance that the ignite tick won't occur due to the thing dying or it being dispelled. They would most likely just make a bigger ignite tick overwrite a smaller one and then refresh the debuff with no stacking being involved. Sure it would hurt Firemage PvE dps but most likely wouldn't bring it down far enough for it to be considered subpar in relation to other classes and then they address the issue in some way shape or form in WoLK to make Fire work again as a spec.

#420SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Eyegore
So, I hate to be the guy that asks the fantastically stupid question, but I am new to the mage game and am intrigued but somewhat confused by the present rolling ignite discussion. I am not sure I have a full grip on _specifically_ what is meant by rolling an ignite, and hope that my question may have at least some merit in bringing others up to speed as well on what seems to be a relatively obscure mechanic.

How I gather blizzard intends ignite to work: Fireball 1 crits triggering the ignite dot. Then FB 2 crits. The tick damage from 1 and 2 is added until there has been enough ticks that the ignite from FB 1 would have expired, then ignite ticks out at the damage based just on FB 2. If this is wrong then I have been operating on incorrect assumptions from the start and am making an even bigger fool of myself than I was hoping for.

Now, Rolling ignites? Am I to understand that landing a FB at just the right moment can be beneficial how: causing the damage component of the first crit from not dropping off the ignite, causing the ignite damage to be calculated wrong (based on the FB damage and the simultaneous ignite tick?), triggering more ignite ticks than should occur somehow, or what?

Again I apologize for what must be an annoyingly elementary question for most of you. But there has been so much discussion of rolling ignites that searching the term gave me pages and pages of posts that all were discussing the topic, but without explaining the underlying assumptions. And I would very much like to be able to follow the current discussion.
#421SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Rounced

Can't balance the game in absencia.

210% crits upfront for ignite ain't gonna happen ever.

PvE reason against - 210% is balanced by the thing dying before the ignite has a chance to tick through - happens on both bosses and on trash. Also balanced by the very real danger that ignite can present if it happens to tick after an aggro reset.

PvP reason against - AP + PoM + Pyro from a mage with 2/2 Spellpower
#422SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1• Astrylian
An Ignite debuff is supposed to do, lets say, X damage (where X is 40% of what the crit fireball hit for). It's expected to tick twice, so has 2 ticks for X/2.

Then suppose that another fireball crits after the first one has ticked once. That one is supposed to do Y damage (where Y is 40% of what the 2nd crit fireball hit for). But there's already an ignite on the target, with X/2 damage remaining on it. So, that X/2 damage is added to the new ignite, which replaces the old one. So the X ignite is dropped, and a new ignite is applied, which does Y+X/2 damage total, or rather Y/2+X/4 per tick. In the end, a total of X+Y damage is done, which is what is intended.

That's what's supposed to happen, anyway. Rolling Ignites is when we use a bug to roll more of the previous ignite into the next one than is intended. For example, if we hit fireball Y right as ignite X is about to have its first tick, it thinks that no ticks have happened yet, so adds the full damage of ignite X into ignite Y, then X ticks, then Y is applied. That results in a total damage done of 3X/2+Y damage done, ie an extra X/2.
#423SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1◊ manly
Originally Posted by Rounced
Can't balance the game in absencia.

210% crits upfront for ignite ain't gonna happen ever.

PvE reason against - 210% is balanced by the thing dying before the ignite has a chance to tick through - happens on both bosses and on trash. Also balanced by the very real danger that ignite can present if it happens to tick after an aggro reset.

PvP reason against - AP + PoM + Pyro from a mage with 2/2 Spellpower
By using your logic, arcane/frost frostbolt crits are overpowered in a PVE context.
#424SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Sancus
Can't balance the game in absencia.

210% crits upfront for ignite ain't gonna happen ever.

PvE reason against - 210% is balanced by the thing dying before the ignite has a chance to tick through - happens on both bosses and on trash. Also balanced by the very real danger that ignite can present if it happens to tick after an aggro reset.

PvP reason against - AP + PoM + Pyro from a mage with 2/2 Spellpower
I completely disagree with this - somehow warlocks are balanced with 200% instantaneous crits along with a 20% bonus from Improved Shadow Bolt, this gives them 240% crits on subsequent crits, and no one is complaining that Warlocks do overpowered burst damage in pvp.

I would argue that the reason ignite is 210% helps to make Fire Mage crit benefit somewhat more comparable to Warlocks, if you just removed it and made it 200% straight up, that would simply be worse in every way, which makes no sense.

It seems to me that you could re-implement Ignite as an instantaneous seperate-damage proc and it would not be especially unbalanced. It isn't like Fire Mages are tearing up the pvp statistics in the first place, this change would make their burst damage a little scarier, but so what? Frost would still have more reliable and better burst in terms of Shatter Combo anyway.
#425SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1Arcanisx
The only reason you saw it tick off the second ignite tick vs the first one was because the fireball on the first ignite didn't crit. Ignite ticks in 2s intervals after it's been applied, so if I would have waited for the second ignite dot PURPOSELY to try and get rolling ignite effect, I would have completely missed 1 fireball's worth of damage. In order to get it to go only off the second ignite, you'd have to be at 2.09s fireball+2s to get it on the second rather than the first, which is a significant dps loss as well as pointless.
#426SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1

Originally Posted by Sancus
I completely disagree with this - somehow warlocks are balanced with 200% instantaneous crits along with a 20% bonus from Improved Shadow Bolt, this gives them 240% crits on subsequent crits, and no one is complaining that Warlocks do overpowered burst damage in pvp.

I think that, arcane/fire aside, PVP would be fine would the ignite damage not be delayed but integral part of the damage. With this said, I do agree that arcane/fire has some burst potential that would be indeed quite absurd.

As for other real 'solutions' to fix this issue, I am totally unsure. Moving down to one tick would not remove the bug (just make it harder to reproduce, but give twice the efficiency).

#427SourcePosted on Patch 2.4.1
Edited onPatch 2.4.1		Sancus
Originally Posted by manly
Well, technically you could argue up to a point that if ISB was already up that it remained 200% crit multiplier all along. I don't think we can draw any direct parallels comparing classes. However, you could also make combustion turn the 'old ignite' into a direct damage component, which would make arcane/fire unaffected. In other words, without combustion you get the old style ignite, with combustion all your crits will do the damage directly.

As for other real 'solutions' to fix this issue, I am totally unsure. Moving down to one tick would not remove the bug (just make it harder to reproduce, but give twice the efficiency).

---- EDIT: yeah well the combustion idea is nice, but it also means you could do rolling ignites by not speccing in combustion. Maybe do it for 1/5+ emp. fireball?
How about making Ignite 175%(+spell power becomes 200, vs 225% for frost) and then making Empowered Fireball add 7% per rank for a final 210% crit multiplier if you go fully into Fire.

That solves the problem, gives deep fire a boost in pvp for burst damage, and leaves arcane/fire about the same - it gains a very small amount of burst(200% crits from 175%), but loses the ignite dot damage completely. Given that it currently is not the dominant pvp spec, that seems reasonable, and deep fire could absolutely use the increased burst damage since it lacks AP and PoM Pyro, and Combustion is terrible in pvp.

The nicest thing about this solution is it's all accomplished with existing code, no new code would need to be written to just alter our crit modifier with two separate talents, and the entire mess that Ignite is goes away.

I would in fact, go so far as to argue that it might be fair to drop Ignite down to 3 talent points this way, freeing up 2 points for utility/pvp talents in normal pve builds, which would be handy.
